If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m ^ n) ↔ Even m ∧ n ≠ 0
name: Nat.even_pow
docString:
If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

For all natural numbers m and n, m^n is even if and only if m is even and n is not zero.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m ^ n) ↔ Even m ∧ n ≠ 0
statement: theorem Nat.even_pow : ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m ^ n) ↔ Even m ∧ n ≠ 0 := by sorry
name: Nat.even_pow
docString:
If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.
description: The theorem `Nat.even_pow` states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, the statement "The number `m` raised to the power `n` is even" is equivalent to the statement "The number `m` is even and `n` is not zero". Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers (in other words, it is a multiple of 2).
concise-description: For all natural numbers m and n, m^n is even if and only if m is even and n is not zero.

If `n : ℕ+` is different from `1`, then it is the successor of some `k : ℕ+`.

name: PNat.exists_eq_succ_of_ne_one
docString: If `n : ℕ+` is different from `1`, then it is the successor of some `k : ℕ+`.

For any natural numbers n and a, n is even if and only if a is even implies the remainder of n divided by a is even.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Even (n % a) ↔ Even n)
name: Even.mod_even_iff
docString: For any natural numbers n and a, n is even if and only if a is even implies the remainder of n divided by a is even.

This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, the number is either even or odd. A natural number `n` is defined as even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as odd if it can be expressed as `2*k + 1` for some number `k`. Thus, the theorem asserts that any natural number fits one of these two definitions.

name: Nat.even_or_odd
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, the number is either even or odd. A natural number `n` is defined as even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as odd if it can be expressed as `2*k + 1` for some number `k`. Thus, the theorem asserts that any natural number fits one of these two definitions.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

name: Nat.dvd_right_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

For any natural number n, the remainder of n when divided by 2 is either 0 or 1. (Equivalently, every natural number is either even or odd.)

name: Nat.mod_two_eq_zero_or_one
docString: For any natural number n, the remainder of n when divided by 2 is either 0 or 1. (Equivalently, every natural number is either even or odd.)

This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `n` and `m`, the product of the successor of `n` (i.e., `n + 1` in common mathematical notation) and `m` is equal to the sum of the product of `n` and `m`, and `m`. In standard mathematical notation, this is saying that for all natural numbers n and m, (n + 1) * m = n * m + m. This is a basic property of natural number arithmetic, reflecting the distributive law.

type: ∀ (n m : ℕ), n.succ * m = n * m + m
name: Nat.succ_mul
docString: This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `n` and `m`, the product of the successor of `n` (i.e., `n + 1` in common mathematical notation) and `m` is equal to the sum of the product of `n` and `m`, and `m`. In standard mathematical notation, this is saying that for all natural numbers n and m, (n + 1) * m = n * m + m. This is a basic property of natural number arithmetic, reflecting the distributive law.

`x^n`, `n : ℕ` is convex on the whole real line whenever `n` is even.

type: ∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedCommRing 𝕜] {n : ℕ}, Even n → ConvexOn 𝕜 Set.univ fun x => x ^ n
name: Even.convexOn_pow
docString: `x^n`, `n : ℕ` is convex on the whole real line whenever `n` is even.

For every natural number `n` greater than zero, `n` is the product of its prime factors.

name: Nat.prod_factors
docString: For every natural number `n` greater than zero, `n` is the product of its prime factors.

The theorem `Nat.even_pow` states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, the statement "The number `m` raised to the power `n` is even" is equivalent to the statement "The number `m` is even and `n` is not zero". Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers (in other words, it is a multiple of 2).

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m ^ n) ↔ Even m ∧ n ≠ 0
name: Nat.even_pow
docString: The theorem `Nat.even_pow` states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, the statement "The number `m` raised to the power `n` is even" is equivalent to the statement "The number `m` is even and `n` is not zero". Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers (in other words, it is a multiple of 2).

A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, (∃ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) ↔ ∀ {q : ℕ}, Nat.Prime q → q % 4 = 3 → Even (padicValNat q n)
name: Nat.eq_sq_add_sq_iff
docString:
A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

`n : ℕ` is perfect if and only the sum of the proper divisors of `n` is `n` and `n`
is positive.

name: Nat.Perfect
docString:
`n : ℕ` is perfect if and only the sum of the proper divisors of `n` is `n` and `n`
is positive.

The divisors of a product of natural numbers are the pointwise product of the divisors of the
factors.

type: ∀ (m n : ℕ), Nat.divisors (m * n) = Nat.divisors m * Nat.divisors n
name: Nat.divisors_mul
docString:
The divisors of a product of natural numbers are the pointwise product of the divisors of the
factors.
